writing_prompt: A master art forger turned FBI consultant finds himself at a crossroads when his old partner proposes a heist that feels... wrong. For the first time, he hesitates—has he really changed, or is he just fooling himself?
story:
"Neiman's been sniffing around for a new score," Neal Caffrey said, his eyes scanning the crowded coffee shop as he leaned in to whisper to Peter Burke. "He wants us to meet him at the old warehouse at midnight."

Peter raised an eyebrow, his expression skeptical. "What's the job?"

Neal hesitated, a flicker of uncertainty crossing his face before he regained his usual charm. "I'm not entirely sure. He just said it's a 'piece of art' that needs to be, ah, liberated."

Peter's expression turned even more dubious. "A piece of art? That sounds like a euphemism for something very specific."

Neal shrugged, trying to appear nonchalant despite the growing unease in his stomach. "Maybe. But like I said, I'm not entirely sure what we're looking at. Neiman's been a bit... evasive on the details."

Peter's eyes narrowed. "You're not buying it, are you?"

Neal's gaze darted around the coffee shop, ensuring they were out of earshot before he leaned in closer to Peter. "Let's just say I have my reservations. This feels... off. And it's not just the fact that Neiman's been dodgy about the details. It's... it feels like something he'd do just for the thrill of it. The rush of adrenaline, the thrill of getting away with something. And I'm not sure I'm comfortable being a part of it."

Peter's expression softened, a look of understanding crossing his face. "You're worried about going back to your old life, aren't you? The one where you were a master art forger, always looking over your shoulder, never staying in one place for too long."

Neal's eyes dropped, a mix of emotions swirling inside him. He had thought he'd left that life behind, had thought he'd truly changed when he'd turned himself in to the FBI and started working with Peter as a consultant. But now, faced with the possibility of going back to his old ways, he wasn't so sure.

"I don't know what's real anymore," Neal admitted, his voice barely above a whisper. "I've been telling myself that I've changed, that I'm a better person now, but what if that's just a lie? What if I'm just fooling myself, and I'm still the same old Neal Caffrey, always looking for the next big score, the next thrill?"

Peter reached out, placing a hand on Neal's arm. "You're not the same person you were back then, Neal. You've grown, you've changed. And I believe you."

Neal looked up at Peter, a surge of gratitude washing over him. "Thanks, Pete. That means a lot coming from you."

The two of them sat in silence for a moment, watching as the coffee shop bustled around them. Finally, Peter spoke up.

"So, what do you want to do? Do you want to meet with Neiman and see what he's got, or do you want to call him and tell him we're not interested?"

Neal hesitated, weighing his options. Part of him wanted to go through with the heist, to see if he could still pull it off, to recapture the thrill of his old life. But another part of him, a part that was growing louder by the minute, was screaming at him to walk away, to leave the past behind and forge a new future.

"I don't know," Neal admitted, his voice barely above a whisper. "I need some time to think about it."

Peter nodded, his expression understanding. "Take all the time you need, Neal. We'll figure this out together."

As they left the coffee shop, Neal couldn't shake the feeling that he was standing at a crossroads, with two paths stretching out before him. He could go back to his old life, to the thrill of the heist, the rush of adrenaline, or he could forge a new path, one where he left his past behind and started fresh.

For the first time in a long time, Neal felt truly uncertain about his future, and it was a feeling he wasn't sure he was ready to face.

writing_prompt: When Crowley ran into Dean Winchester after years apart, he never expected it to lead to late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and a life tangled with federal agents and family barbecues. But some things, it seems, are worth rewriting the plan for.
story:
Crowley's eyes narrowed as he watched the familiar figure emerge from the dimly lit alleyway. Years had passed since their last encounter, and the world had changed in ways he never could have predicted. Yet, there was something undeniably...familiar about the way Dean Winchester strode towards him, a confident air about him that only seemed to grow more pronounced with each passing year.

Their initial meeting was marked by the usual banter, the familiar dance of words that had once passed for friendship, but Crowley knew better. He'd long since seen through the facade, and Dean's motives had never been as pure as they seemed. Still, the years apart had softened the edges of his animosity, leaving behind a lingering sense of...nostalgia.

"What brings you to town, Dean?" Crowley asked, his voice low and measured as he fell into step beside the hunter.

"Business," Dean replied, his eyes scanning the surrounding area with a practiced air of caution. "I'm tracking a lead on a potential case. Thought I'd stop by and see if you'd heard anything."

Crowley raised an eyebrow. "You think I'm some sort of informant now?"

Dean flashed a wry smile. "Hey, you're a demon, Crowley. You've got connections. I figured it was worth a shot."

Their conversation flowed easily, a comfortable rhythm that spoke to the years they'd spent navigating the supernatural world together. Crowley found himself relaxing in Dean's presence, letting his guard down in ways he wouldn't have thought possible.

As the night wore on, they found themselves at a small, out-of-the-way diner, sipping coffee and swapping stories of their respective adventures. Crowley couldn't help but be drawn in by Dean's infectious enthusiasm, his passion for the hunt a palpable thing that left Crowley feeling...inspired.

It wasn't until they stumbled out of the diner, laughing and joking like old times, that Crowley realized the true extent of his feelings. The world around him seemed to tilt, the shadows deepening into a rich, velvety darkness that seemed to pulse with a life of its own.

"Dean?" Crowley said, his voice barely above a whisper as he reached out to brush a strand of hair from the hunter's forehead.

Dean's eyes flickered towards him, a spark of awareness igniting in their depths. For a moment, they simply stared at each other, the air thick with tension as the world around them melted away.

Then, without warning, Dean leaned in, his lips brushing against Crowley's in a soft, gentle kiss. The demon's heart skipped a beat, his mind reeling as he wrapped his arms around the hunter's waist, deepening the kiss.

It was a moment of pure, unadulterated chaos, the kind of thing that would have gotten them both killed if anyone had seen them. But Crowley didn't care. For the first time in centuries, he felt alive, his heart pounding in his chest like a drum.

As they broke apart, gasping for air, Crowley smiled up at Dean, his eyes shining with a mixture of excitement and trepidation.

"I never expected this," he said, his voice barely above a whisper.

Dean's smile was slow, his eyes crinkling at the corners as he leaned in to kiss Crowley again.

"I know," he replied, his lips brushing against the demon's ear. "But sometimes, you just have to go with the plan."

The weeks that followed were a blur of stolen moments and clandestine meetings, their relationship blossoming like a wildflower in the desert. They navigated the treacherous landscape of the supernatural world together, their love growing stronger with each passing day.

And yet, despite the chaos that surrounded them, they found a strange sort of peace in each other's company. A peace that only grew stronger when they were surrounded by the people they loved – Sam, Bobby, and even the occasional federal agent who stumbled into their orbit.

As they sat on the porch of Bobby's cabin, watching the sun set over the trees, Crowley turned to Dean with a smile.

"You know, I never thought I'd say this to you, but...I'm glad we ran into each other."

Dean's eyes crinkled at the corners as he reached out to brush a strand of hair from Crowley's forehead.

"Me too," he said, his voice low and sincere. "I never expected to find this with you, but...I'm glad we did."

Their lips met in a soft, gentle kiss, the world around them fading into the background as they lost themselves in the moment.

Some things, it seemed, were worth rewriting the plan for.

writing_prompt: A con artist turned FBI consultant accidentally finds himself defending proper legal procedures during a heated case discussion—much to the amusement of his by-the-book handler, who never lets him live it down.
story:
Neal Caffrey leaned back in his chair, a confident smirk spreading across his face as he began to spin a tale of his latest, greatest heist. It wasn't every day that he got to recount his exploits in the comfort of an FBI office, and he was determined to make the most of it.

Peter Burke, Neal's handler and the epitome of by-the-book, raised an eyebrow as he listened to Neal's exaggerated account of the art gallery caper. "Let me get this straight, Neal," Peter said, his voice dry and skeptical. "You managed to con the entire security system, swap the paintings with forgeries, and make off with a small fortune, all without being caught?"

Neal nodded, a look of mock innocence on his face. "Hey, I'm a professional, Peter. I've got it down to a science."

Just then, a group of agents burst into the room, arguing heatedly about a case they were working on. "I'm telling you, we need to get a warrant," one of them said, his voice rising. "We can't just barge in there without probable cause."

Neal watched the exchange with interest, his mind whirring as he followed the conversation. "Probable cause, probable cause," he muttered to himself. "Sounds like a bunch of bureaucratic red tape to me."

Peter caught his eye and raised an eyebrow. "You know, Neal, for a con artist, you're surprisingly clueless about the law."

Neal bristled, but before he could respond, he found himself drawn into the conversation. "Actually, Peter, I think I see what they're getting at. If they don't have probable cause, they can't get a warrant, and they can't enter the premises. But if they do have probable cause, then they can get a warrant and search the place. It's all about following procedure, right?"

The agents turned to him, surprised. "How do you know this?" one of them asked.

Neal shrugged, trying to play it cool. "Oh, just a little something I picked up from my extensive research on the FBI's favorite procedures."

Peter's eyes rolled, but the agents looked impressed. "Actually, Neal, that's exactly right," one of them said. "We do need to follow procedure to the letter."

Neal beamed, feeling a strange sense of pride. "See, Peter? I told you I'm a quick learner."

Peter just shook his head. "You're a menace, Neal. A menace with a knack for getting us into trouble."

As the agents continued to discuss their case, Neal found himself getting more and more drawn into the conversation. He began to realize that, despite his initial skepticism, he actually had a bit of a soft spot for proper procedure. It was almost... comforting, in a way.

The agents eventually left the room, still arguing, but Neal remained, lost in thought. Peter raised an eyebrow. "You know, Neal, I never thought I'd say this, but you actually seemed to enjoy defending procedure."

Neal shrugged, trying to play it cool. "Hey, it's all about being adaptable, Peter. And who knows? Maybe one day I'll even become a real FBI agent."

Peter's expression turned incredulous. "Don't hold your breath, Neal. You'd last about five minutes in the field."

Neal grinned, feeling a spark of mischief ignite within him. "Oh, I don't know, Peter. I think I'd make a great agent. I've already got the skills – I'm a master of disguise, a genius at manipulation, and I've got a heart of gold."

Peter raised an eyebrow. "You're a menace, Neal. A menace with a bad sense of humor."

As the conversation continued, Neal couldn't help but feel a strange sense of belonging. For the first time in his life, he felt like he was part of something bigger than himself – something that actually mattered.

And as he looked over at Peter, he knew that he'd never let him live down his little stint as a procedure defender. But for now, he was content to bask in the warmth of his newfound appreciation for the law.

As the day drew to a close, Neal packed up his things and headed out the door, feeling a sense of satisfaction that he hadn't felt in a long time. Who knew that being a consultant for the FBI would actually be good for him?

As he walked out into the bright sunlight, Neal couldn't help but wonder what other surprises the future held. But one thing was for sure – he'd always be there to defend procedure, much to Peter's chagrin.

And as he disappeared into the crowd, Peter shook his head, a small smile playing on his lips. "Only Neal Caffrey would turn a con artist's life into a career as a procedure defender."

The door closed behind Neal, and Peter couldn't help but chuckle to himself. He had a feeling that this was going to be a long and interesting partnership.

writing_prompt: The starship is stranded, dead in space, with no apparent reason for the failure. As the clock ticks down and theories crumble, the chief engineer must uncover the truth before the crew's time runs out.
story:
"Systems Failure: Dead in Space"

Chief Engineer Montgomery Scott stood at the helm of the engineering console, his eyes scanning the maze of screens and dials for any sign of life. The USS Enterprise hung motionless, a tomb of metal and wires drifting through the void. The silence was oppressive, punctuated only by the soft hum of backup systems and the gentle hiss of life support.

"Captain's Log, Stardate 5221.5," Scott's voice echoed through the ship's intercom, his words a monotone reminder of the dire situation. "The Enterprise has suffered a catastrophic failure, with all systems down and no apparent reason for the malfunction. The crew is working to diagnose the problem, but so far, no solution has been found."

Scott's gaze drifted to the console in front of him, where Lieutenant Uhura's worried face stared back. "Bones, we're running out of time," she said, her voice tight with concern. "If we can't find a way to get the ship moving, we'll be drifting here forever."

Dr. Leonard McCoy, the Enterprise's chief medical officer, shook his head. "I don't know what to tell you, Uhura. We've run every test, checked every system, and nothing's showing up. It's like the ship just... gave up."

The words hung in the air like a challenge, and Scott's face set in a determined line. "We'll find out what's wrong, and we'll fix it. That's what engineers do."

As the hours ticked by, the crew worked tirelessly to diagnose the problem. Scott and his team scoured the ship, running tests and checking every inch of the engineering systems. But with each passing minute, hope began to dwindle.

"Captain's Log, Supplemental," Scott's voice came over the intercom again. "We've tried everything. The ship's dead, and we're running out of options. If we don't find a solution soon, we'll be facing... unpleasant consequences."

The words trailed off, leaving an uncomfortable silence in their wake. Scott's eyes met Uhura's, and for a moment, they just looked at each other, the weight of their failure pressing down on them.

It was then that Scott remembered a conversation he'd had with the Enterprise's captain, James T. Kirk, months ago. "The best engineers are the ones who think outside the box," Kirk had said, his eyes sparkling with mischief. "Don't be afraid to try the impossible, Scotty. That's where the real innovation happens."

Scott's mind whirled as he stared at the console in front of him. What if the problem wasn't a technical one at all? What if it was something... else?

With a newfound sense of purpose, Scott called his team together. "Alright, lads and lasses. We've been looking at this problem from the wrong angle. It's time to think outside the box."

The team exchanged skeptical glances, but Scott's determination was infectious. Together, they began to brainstorm, throwing out wild theories and half-baked ideas. It was a chaotic, messy process, but Scott knew that sometimes, that's where the best solutions lay.

As the hours ticked by, the crew worked tirelessly, fueled by Scott's infectious enthusiasm. And then, like a bolt of lightning on a stormy night, it hit them.

"Captain's Log, Supplemental," Scott's voice came over the intercom once more. "We've found the problem. It's not a technical issue at all. It's... psychological."

The crew stared at him, stunned. "Psychological?" Uhura repeated. "What do you mean, Scotty?"

Scott's face was set in a determined line. "The ship's been experiencing... anxiety. It's been feeling trapped, confined, and it's reacted by shutting down all systems. We need to find a way to calm it down, to make it feel safe again."

The crew exchanged awed glances. It was a crazy idea, but it just might work.

With Scott's guidance, the crew worked to create a system that would calm the ship's anxiety. It was a delicate process, but eventually, they managed to create a soothing melody that seemed to quiet the ship's concerns.

As the Enterprise's systems began to hum back to life, the crew breathed a collective sigh of relief. They'd done it – they'd found a way to save the ship.

"Captain's Log, Supplemental," Scott's voice came over the intercom once more. "The Enterprise is back online, and we're making our way back to Federation space. It's been a long, hard road, but in the end, it was just a matter of thinking outside the box."

As the ship hurtled through space, Scott smiled to himself. Sometimes, the most impossible solutions were the ones that lay just outside the edge of reality. And sometimes, all it took was a little bit of creativity and a lot of determination to save the day.

writing_prompt: When a relentless agent arrives to audit Peter's team, Neal finds himself under suspicion for a forgery he didn’t commit. To clear his name—and protect Peter—he hatches a plan that might just blur the line between clever and reckless.
story:
Peter sat at his desk, the phone pressed to his ear as he listened to the stern voice on the other end. "I'm afraid I have some...unsettling news, Agent Fowler," he said, his tone calm despite the growing sense of unease in his chest.

Fowler's voice dripped with an air of superiority. "I've received reports that a forgery has gone through your team, and I'm here to investigate. I suggest you prepare your people for questioning."

Peter's eyes scanned the room, locking onto Neal, who was scribbling in a notebook with an air of quiet intensity. He raised an eyebrow, and Neal flashed him a reassuring smile before refocusing on his work.

When Peter hung up the phone, he let out a deep breath and turned to Neal. "It seems we have a visitor. Agent Fowler is on his way to audit our team, and I have a feeling it's not going to be a pleasant experience."

Neal's head snapped up, his eyes lighting with a mischievous spark. "I've got a feeling it's going to be worse than that. Fowler's got a reputation for being...thorough. And I think he's got his sights set on me."

Peter's expression turned skeptical. "What makes you think that?"

Neal shrugged. "I've done some digging. Fowler's been poking around, asking questions about my past...and I think he's looking for a way to tie me to the forgery."

Peter's eyes narrowed. "We'll figure this out, Neal. But in the meantime, let's make sure you're prepared. Just in case."

Neal nodded, his smile never wavering. But as he continued to work, Peter could see the gears turning in his mind. He knew that look – the one that said Neal was cooking up a plan, and it was going to be big.

As it turned out, Neal's plan was bigger than Peter had anticipated. When Agent Fowler arrived, Neal was sitting at his desk, looking as innocent as a lamb. But Peter knew better. He could see the tension in Neal's shoulders, the way his eyes darted around the room as he took in the surroundings.

Fowler was a tall, imposing figure, with a stern expression that made Peter's skin crawl. "So, I hear you're the one who's been causing trouble," he said, his voice dripping with disdain.

Neal's smile never wavered. "Trouble? Me? Never. I'm just a humble forger, trying to make a living in this crazy world."

Fowler raised an eyebrow. "Save it, kid. I've seen your work. You're a master forger, and I'm here to take you down."

Neal leaned back in his chair, looking relaxed. "I'm shaking in my boots, Agent. But I think you've got the wrong guy. I mean, I've done some...questionable things in my past, but forgery? That's not my style."

Fowler's expression turned skeptical. "Really? So what do you think happened to the forgery?"

Neal's eyes sparkled with mischief. "Oh, I think it was a clever ruse, designed to throw you off the scent. Maybe someone – someone with a talent for forgery, let's say – decided to leave a trail of breadcrumbs to distract you."

Fowler's eyes narrowed. "And who might that someone be?"

Neal shrugged. "I have no idea. But I think it's time we brought in some outside help. Someone with a...fresh perspective on things."

Before Peter could stop him, Neal had picked up the phone and dialed a number. "Hey, Sara? We need your expertise. Agent Fowler's here, and he's got us in his sights. Can you come down and help us out?"

Sara's voice came through the phone, calm and collected. "Of course, Neal. I'll be right there."

As they waited for Sara to arrive, Peter exchanged a skeptical look with Neal. "You're not exactly selling me on this plan, Neal."

Neal just grinned. "Trust me, Peter. This is going to work. And even if it doesn't...well, at least we'll have fun trying."

Sara arrived just as Fowler was finishing up his questioning. She listened attentively as Neal repeated his story, her expression growing more and more skeptical.

Finally, she turned to Fowler. "I think I see the problem here, Agent. You're looking at this from the wrong angle. Neal's not a forger – at least, not in the classical sense. He's more of a...renovator. He likes to take things apart and put them back together in new and interesting ways."

Fowler's expression turned confused. "A renovator?"

Sara nodded. "Yes. And I think I can help you see what Neal's trying to tell you. Let's take a look at the evidence, shall we?"

As Sara began to examine the evidence, Neal leaned back in his chair, looking smug. Peter shot him a warning look, but Neal just winked at him.

It wasn't until Sara had finished examining the evidence and Fowler had left, looking defeated, that Peter turned to Neal and asked, "What did you just do?"

Neal grinned. "I told you it would work, Peter. I just...renovated the evidence a bit. Made it look like someone else was responsible for the forgery."

Peter's eyes widened. "You can't be serious. That's...reckless, Neal."

Neal shrugged. "Hey, it worked, didn't it? And besides, I'm not exactly breaking any rules. I'm just...reinterpreting them."

As Peter shook his head, laughing, Neal leaned back in his chair, looking satisfied. "See, Peter? I told you it would be fun."
